title-group.article-title: The Cyclicality of New Product Introductions*

permissions.copyright-statement: © 2003 by The University of Chicago. All rights reserved.

abstract.p: This study analyzes empirically the cyclical nature of the timing of new product introductions in U.S. manufacturing. New product introductions vary more in nonseasonal frequencies than in seasonal frequencies. However, the seasons alone account for only a small part of their total variability with demand factors being much more important. Demand fluctuations account for 35%–80% and 17%–43%, respectively, of the seasonal and cyclical variability of new product introductions in various industries. Finally, new product introductions respond more to fluctuations in aggregate demand than in market demand and in business cycles than in seasonal cycles.

fn.p: I would like to thank Abdul Ali, Anirudh Dhebar, Hsiang‐Ling Han, and Erik Sirri for interesting discussions and helpful feedback. I am also grateful to an anonymous referee for very valuable comments. All remaining errors are my own.

sec.label: I.
sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Successful new products are vital for a company’s success in the marketplace. Early in 1997 Toyota Motor Co. showed a 17% increase in its U.S. sales of light vehicles at the same time that some of its main competitors experienced declining sales.1“Our competitors have been slow to launch new products” was the explanation provided by Yale Gieszl, executive vice president of the company’s U.S. unit.2The introduction of new products seems critical also for the beef industry in its efforts to stop its recent sales decline and prevent its consumers from switching to other types of food. “We need to come up with new products, new marketing, new distribution. We must be on the offensive” was the recommendation offered to the beef industry by Tim Strauss, an industry consultant.3Finally, in response to slow sales of Christmas candy, companies introduce new products hoping to draw consumers’ attention and revitalize sales.4

However, the timing for launching new products is critical for their market success, and companies carefully analyze the market conditions before introducing their new products. Late in the summer of 1998 IBM introduced a new low‐end Aptiva PC targeted to students during the competitive back‐to‐school shopping season.5A few months later, in October 1998, IBM introduced another Aptiva multimedia PC in anticipation of the usually strong Christmas sales season. Finally, food companies, in preparation for Christmas, use red dye and green sprinkles in the Christmas versions of their products.6There is plenty of anecdotal evidence indicating not only the importance of new products for the company’s market success but also the fact that there are some distinct time patterns that companies follow in launching their new products.

The timing of new product introductions has drawn significant research interest. Researchers traditionally have analyzed the introduction of new products within the context of product line expansions. Given the market size of its industry, the company makes a strategic decision—by introducing new products—in an effort to stimulate its total sales and increase profits. It is usually assumed that companies consider introducing one or two products of the same or different quality, and the optimal timing is determined when they maximize either their profits or their sales.

Specifically, Wilson and Norton (1989) claim that the optimal timing of introducing two new products—one as a line extension and the other as an improved product—depends on the degree of substitutability between the two. Moorthy and Png (1992) analyze the timing of introducing two new products in the market—one of a high quality, and the other of low quality. They find that a sequential introduction of the two products alleviates cannibalization by forcing consumers of the lower‐end product to wait before they make a purchase. With this strategy, the company balances the benefits of weaker cannibalization against the postponement of profits from the low‐end product. In a similar fashion, Putsis (1993) argues that companies might delay the introduction of high‐technology products until the need for growth is greater than the fear of cannibalizing their existing products. Finally, Kalish and Lilien (1986) emphasize the drawbacks from mistiming the introduction of a new product, while Lilien and Yoon (1990) test empirically the relation between the timing of a new product introduction and its market success.

Other researchers study the impact of the competitive market environment on the timing of new product introductions. Krider and Weinberg (1998) point out that, in the motion picture industry, movie studios plan the release of their movies during seasons of high demand, such as Christmas and summer. They also find that the expected market success of a movie in relation to competing movies from other studios is very important for deciding the exact timing of its release.

Of course, the development and commercialization process of a new product might take longer than expected, so the company might miss the high‐demand season.7Then it has the option either to launch the product immediately or to wait for the next high‐demand season. Radas and Shugan (1998) discuss the conditions that influence companies to postpone the launch of their new products until the next high‐demand season. On a similar note, Chatterjee and Sugita (1990), in a game theoretic model and in the presence of uncertainty in market demand, discuss the factors that determine the strategic decision of a company to launch a new product immediately or to postpone the launch for a later time.

Finally, Devinney (1990) studies empirically the impact of business cycle demand fluctuations on the timing of new product introductions. He finds that the business cycle slightly lags the introduction of new products, or that companies introduce new products in anticipation of the revival of the economy. However, the fluctuations of the industry demand are left out from his analysis.

This article, in an effort to address ample anecdotal evidence, studies empirically the timing patterns of new product introductions and the impact of market (industry) and aggregate demand fluctuations on these patterns. Using data on new product introductions that span 10 years and come from five two‐digit SIC (standard industrial classification) industries in the United States, I first measure the variability of new product introductions at different frequencies (i.e., at seasonal and business cycle frequencies). I then estimate the impact of market and aggregate demand fluctuations on the timing of new product introductions.

The article is organized as follows:Section IIincludes a theoretical motivation of the testable hypotheses. InSection III, the data used in the analysis are described.Section IVdiscusses the cyclical patterns of new product introductions.Section Vemphasizes the impact of market and aggregate demand fluctuations on new product introductions at seasonal and nonseasonal frequencies.Section VIdiscusses the robustness of the empirical results to alternative treatments of the data. Conclusions are inSection VII.

fn.p: Ford Motor Co. and General Motors Corp. had a 3% and a 7.4% drop, respectively, in their sales of light vehicles at the same period.
“Toyota Posts 17% Increase in Car Sales,”Wall Street Journal(March 5, 1997).
“Beef Industry Ads Focus on Simplicity and Nutrition to Win Back Consumers,”Wall Street Journal(November 24, 1999).
“Christmas Isn’t so Sweet for Seasonal Candy Makers,”Wall Street Journal(December 14, 1999).
“IBM to Unveil Aptiva PC Aimed at Schoolchildren,”Wall Street Journal(July 15, 1998).
“Food: Ingredients for Holiday Sales: Red Dye, Green Sprinkles,”Wall Street Journal(July 15, 1997).
See Droge, Jayaram, and Vickery (2000).

sec.label: II.
sec.title: Theoretical Motivation
sec.p: The anecdotal evidence presented already indicates the importance of market demand for the timing of new product introductions. In the economics literature this relation comes as a by‐product of the extensive discussion on product variety. Both the neo‐Chamberlinian models and the locational models suggest that, as market demand expands, more companies enter the market offering a differentiated product, resulting in more new products in the market.8However, these models have several limitations since they are usually static and assume a monopolistically competitive environment.

Launching a new product in the market is a multiperiod dynamic process with uncertain profitability and happens usually in the context of an oligopolistic market environment. Chatterjee and Sugita (1990) study theoretically the timing of new product introductions in a symmetric duopolistic model with uncertain market demand for the new product.

However, synchronizing the introduction of new products during seasonal or cyclical expansions of market demand is not always easy, since there might be unexpected delays in developing and launching a new product. If a new product is ready for market launch in an off‐peak season, the company has to decide either to wait for the next high‐demand season or to introduce the product immediately. Radas and Shugan (1998) study this case in relation to seasonal peaks in market demand, but their findings can also be extended for nonseasonal demand expansions. Specifically, they find that companies might postpone the launching of a new product and introduce it when demand expands. They also find that companies’ incentives to synchronize the introduction of new products with periods of high demand become stronger with higher expected demand and lower interest rates. Obviously, low interest rates result in higher present value of future profits, so companies find it more appealing to postpone the launching of their new products for the expected high‐demand season. These insights stimulated the focus of the present article—the impact that the cyclical fluctuations in market and aggregate demand have on the timing of new product introductions.

The cyclical fluctuations of demand, either at seasonal or business cycle frequencies, represent reoccurring expansions and contractions of demand that follow a cyclical pattern and persist for some period of time. The regularity of these fluctuations makes them less uncertain and much more predictable than any other change in demand. Consequently, the uncertainty of new products’ expected profitability in association with these fluctuations in demand might be diminished.

In addition, an expansion in either market or aggregate demand that is expected to last for some time (usually a few months for the seasonal cycle and a few years for the business cycle) increases the likelihood of higher profits for newly introduced products. Therefore, companies have stronger incentives to introduce their new products during a cyclical market‐demand expansion, since these expansions are persistent and rather predictable. At the same time, the predictability of the cyclical demand expansions might make companies postpone the market launching of new products that became ready in a low‐demand season. This intuition is also consistent with the anecdotal evidence already presented where companies introduce their new products in periods of high cyclical demand (Christmas season, etc.).

Furthermore, it is likely that companies can more easily synchronize their new product introductions with the seasonal demand expansions since these expansions are more regular and predictable than those of the business cycle. Hence, it is expected that demand fluctuations can explain more of the seasonal variability of new product introductions than that of the business cycle. On the other hand, in introducing their new products, companies might be more responsive to the business cycle market expansions, since these nationwide expansions are usually stronger and more persistent than the seasonal ones. Notice finally that, in anticipation of the cyclical fluctuations of demand, companies adjust appropriately various other aspects of their operation, such as their production or the level of their inventories (Miron1996). The present study focuses on documenting a similar behavior in terms of new product introductions.

The discussed intuition about the relation between new product introductions and market and aggregate demand can be summarized in the following hypotheses that are tested in the remaining part of the study:
Hypothesis1. The introduction of new products is influenced by the cyclical fluctuations of market and aggregate demand.
Hypothesis2. New product introductions are more responsive to fluctuations in aggregate demand as opposed to market demand.
Hypothesis3. Demand fluctuations explain a larger amount of the seasonal activity of new product introductions than that of the business cycle.
Hypothesis4. New product introductions are more responsive to business cycle demand fluctuations than to seasonal ones.

fn.p: For a comprehensive survey of the literature, see Beath and Katsoulacos (1991).

sec.label: III.
sec.title: Data and Methodology
sec.p: The data on new product introductions were collected from theWall Street Journal(seeapp. A) for the period between 1984 and 1993, following a similar methodology as in Devinney (1990). In particular, using the Dow Jones Retrieval Service, the abstracts of all the articles published in theWall Street Journalfor the entire 10‐year period were reviewed for announcements of new product introductions by companies in all U.S. manufacturing industries. The date of the announcement was recorded as the date that the corresponding product was introduced in the market. Next, all the products were classified across industries according to the two‐digit SIC code. In total 3,669 new products were recorded in all the two‐digit SIC U.S. manufacturing industries for the entire 10‐year period. Finally, the data were grouped by industry and organized on a monthly basis.9

In testing the hypotheses, proxies for both market and aggregate demand are used. The log growth rate of retail sales and the index of industrial production for the industries in the sample are used as a proxy for market demand. On the other hand, the log growth of retail sales and the industrial production for manufacturing are used to proxy aggregate demand and the business cycle.10

Due to limitations of the data for new products, a sample of five industries that show enough variability in the level of new product introductions is used in the empirical analysis.11The sample includes 3,064 of the 3,669 new products in the data set (approximately 84%).

fn.p: See app. A for more on this data set. Skeptics might criticize the collection of the data since it is based solely on one source. Clearly, one newspaper is not expected to record all new products introduced in the market. Also, theWall Street Journalmight be a biased source for collecting data on new products, since it tends to emphasize rather “popular” industries (i.e., electronics, transportation equipment, etc.) and of course does not record all the new products actually introduced in the market. Despite these shortcomings, the data on new products most likely capture the fluctuations of the actual number of products introduced in the market, because any bias in the way the newspaper reports on new products will be consistent over time. In fact Devinney (1993) finds that patent intensity is closely associated with new product introductions, and Cardinal and Opler (1995) find that the degree of corporate diversification of companies does not have any impact on new product innovativeness. These findings are consistent with the fact that the correlation between the data on the number of new products used in the present study and the number of patents issued and trademarks registered annually in the United States between 1984 and 1993 is 0.506 and 0.825, respectively. Using in addition the data on new products collected by Devinney (covering the period between 1975 and 1984), the respective correlations are 0.742 and 0.835. Consequently, the data on new products might proxy well the actual number of new products introduced in the United States.
To proxy better the cyclical patterns of market and aggregate demand, regressors are also lagged a few times.
The five industries are Food and Kindred Products (SIC 20), Chemicals and Allied Products (28), Electrical Machinery (36), Transportation Equipment (37), and Instruments and Related Products (38).

sec.label: IV.
sec.title: Cyclical Patterns in New Product Introductions
sec.p:
TablesB1andB2(app. B) report descriptive statistics and correlations for the most important variables in the analysis.Figure 1shows the seasonality of new products of the industries in the sample.12For all five industries pooled together, February, June, September, and October are the months with the strongest activity in new product introductions. Specifically for Food, September and October are the 2 months when most of the new products are introduced, apparently in anticipation of the strong Christmas sales season. In Electrical Machinery, February and June are also important for new product introductions, in addition to September and October. Chemicals and Instruments show similar seasonal patterns with Food. Finally, many new products in Transportation Equipment are introduced in March, in synchronization with the usually strong spring sales season, and the fall—September through November—which is a very active period for new product introductions in this industry. Overall,figure 1demonstrates vividly the seasonal patterns of new product introductions, with fall being the season where most of the new products are introduced. Fig. 1.—
Seasonality of new product introductions

Previous research (Devinney1990) has shown that the introduction of new products is also driven by nonseasonal fluctuations of economic activity, in particular, the business cycle.Table B3measures the magnitude of the variability of new product introductions in seasonal and nonseasonal frequencies. In calculating the statistics in the table, the level of new product introductions was regressed on monthly dummies. The first statistic is the standard deviation of the fitted values of the regression, and it estimates the standard deviation of the seasonal component of new product introductions. The second statistic is the standard error of the regression, an estimate of the standard deviation of the nonseasonal component of new product introductions. In all five industries, the nonseasonal variation of new products is two to three times larger than the seasonal one, an indication that new product introductions are much smoother over the seasonal cycles. Finally, new product introductions in Electrical Machinery show the strongest nonseasonal component among the other industries in the sample. Overall, new products seem to vary less over the seasons, perhaps because the seasons are very much anticipated by companies, and therefore they can plan more accurately their new product introductions.

fn.p: The vertical axis of every figure measures the monthly average of new product introductions in a specific industry.

sec.label: V.
sec.title: Demand Fluctuations and New Product Introductions

sec.label: A.
sec.title: Seasonal Demand and New Product Introductions
sec.p:
To focus solely on the seasonal variation of the regressors in estimatingequation (1), each regressor (both the dependent and the independent variables) was regressed on seasonal dummies. Then the fitted values, which preserve only the seasonal variation of the corresponding variable, were used in estimatingequation (1). The results are reported intable 1. Table 1

Significance \documentclass{aastex} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{bm} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{pifont} \usepackage{stmaryrd} \usepackage{textcomp} \usepackage{portland,xspace} \usepackage{amsmath,amsxtra} \usepackage[OT2,OT1]{fontenc} \newcommand\cyr{ \renewcommand\rmdefault{wncyr} \renewcommand\sfdefault{wncyss} \renewcommand\encodingdefault{OT2} \normalfont \selectfont} \DeclareTextFontCommand{\textcyr}{\cyr} \pagestyle{empty} \DeclareMathSizes{10}{9}{7}{6} \begin{document} \landscape $\mathrm{level}\,=.025$ \end{document} .

The contemporaneous growth rate of market demand has a negative and statistically significant impact on new product introductions in all but the Transportation Equipment industries. However, the lagged‐by‐1‐month growth rate of market demand has a positive and statistically significant impact on new product introductions in three of the five industries in the sample. In Food, Electrical Machinery, and Transportation Equipment, companies seem to consider the seasonal market expansion and respond with a slight time lag in introducing their new products, while in Chemicals and Instruments this is not the case.

On the other hand, the growth rate of the aggregate demand, contemporaneous and lagged by 1 month, has a positive and statistically significant impact on the introduction of new products in all five industries. Also, the size of this impact is quite large. In seasonal frequencies, a 1% increase in the growth rate of aggregate demand causes new product introductions to increase approximately in the range between 0.12% (Transportation Equipment) to 0.88% (Electrical Machinery). It seems that aggregate demand has an important impact on the timing of new product introductions, indicating that companies also consider the stage of the aggregate economy—besides their own market—in launching their new products in the market.

New product introductions in Electrical Machinery (usually consumer products) respond the most to seasonal market and aggregate demand, while new product introductions in Chemicals and Instruments (mostly industrial products) respond primarily to aggregate demand. Also, the seasonal market and aggregate demand stimulate the introduction of new products with a slight time lag (approximately 1 month). Overall, the data are unable to reject hypothesis 1.

fn.p: All time series that have been used in the estimations in the present study have been tested for unit roots. The Dickey‐Fuller tests (available on request) reject the hypothesis of unit roots in each of the used time series. Also, in all estimations possible, autocorrelation in the errors has been corrected using the Cochrane‐Orcutt procedure.
Sales figures are an alternative proxy for market demand, but these data are seasonally adjusted and therefore not appropriate for the estimations.

sec.label: B.
sec.title: Nonseasonal Demand and New Product Introductions
sec.p: The development and the market launch of new products involve significant spending on R&D, most of which is a sunk cost for the company. Consequently, companies have strong incentives to introduce their new products during an economic expansion in anticipation of strong sales. Devinney (1990) found that new product introductions tend slightly to lead the business cycle, with companies introducing their new products in anticipation of an economic expansion.

In the present section, the same question is tackled. However, I focus solely on the nonseasonal component of the variability of new product introductions after removing their seasonal variability. This is necessary since in many economic activities there is strong interaction between seasonal and nonseasonal variation (Miron1996). Isolating only the nonseasonal component of their variation helps in deriving much more accurate estimations of the tested relations. Consequently, all the data used in estimations are adjusted seasonally.

Aggregate demand is also an important factor in new product introductions. The contemporaneous (and its two lags) growth rate of aggregate demand has a positive and statistically significant impact on new product introductions in almost all cases in the five industries in the sample. Obviously, companies are very much influenced by the stage of the aggregate economy when they introduce their new products, a finding that is consistent with hypothesis 1.

sec.label: C.
sec.title: Responsiveness of New Product Introductions to Demand Fluctuations
sec.p: The empirical results so far indicate that overall aggregate demand both in seasonal and nonseasonal frequencies has a stronger impact on new product introductions than does market demand. For the first, the estimated coefficients range between 0.121 and 2.697, implying that a 1% growth of aggregate demand results on average in a 0.121% to 2.697% increase in new product introductions. For market demand, the coefficients range between 0.037 and 1.033, showing that new product introductions increase in the range between 0.037% and 1.033% in response to a 1% growth of market demand. Companies appear to perceive an aggregate demand expansion as a signal for larger sales opportunities for their new products, since the entire economy is booming and so are other industries to which these companies sell their products as inputs. Hypothesis 2 is also not rejected by the data.

In Electrical Machinery new product introductions show the strongest response to market and aggregate demand fluctuations among the industries in the sample (perhaps due to products with relatively short life cycles). On the other extreme, new products in Transportation Equipment respond the least to market or aggregate demand, perhaps because the seasons by themselves, as discussed already, seem to drive the new product introductions in this industry.

Finally, the estimated coefficients for market and aggregate demand are larger in business cycle frequencies. Business cycle expansions are perceived by companies as strong expansions of economic activity not only for their industry but also for the entire economy. At the same time, these expansions are more persistent and long‐lived than the seasonal ones. Especially in the postwar period, economic recessions in the United States became weaker and slightly shorter and economic expansions much longer (by about 65%) than in the prewar period.15On average, a postwar U.S. recession lasts for 10.7 months, while a U.S. expansion lasts for 56.1 months. Consequently, companies have strong incentives to synchronize the introduction of new products with increasingly larger economic expansions. At the same time, interest rates are procyclical (i.e., they are high in economic expansions and low in economic recessions). Hence, in the case where companies develop a new product during an economic recession, the expected shortness of the recession and the expected strength of the next expansion, along with low interest rates, give them incentives to postpone the launching of their new product until the next economic expansion.16Therefore, companies are likely to react more strongly to business cycle demand expansions when they introduce their new products (hypothesis 4).

Among the industries in the sample, and besides Electrical Machinery, new product introductions in Instruments and Chemicals respond the most to fluctuations in nonseasonal aggregate demand. These are industries that draw sales not only from consumers but primarily from companies, and therefore, when the economy expands, they benefit the most; hence, their strong response to nonseasonal aggregate demand fluctuations. On the other hand, new product introductions in Food—primarily a consumer product industry—are driven by fluctuations in market demand instead of aggregate demand.

fn.p: See Romer (1999).
As it can be inferred from Radas and Shugan (1998).

sec.label: VI.
sec.title: Robustness of the Empirical Results
sec.p: The empirical results in the previous section emphasize the importance of market and aggregate demand fluctuations in determining the timing patterns of new product introductions. In the presentsection Itest the robustness of the results to different methodologies in seasonally adjusting the data and to alternative proxies of market and aggregate demand.

The market and aggregate demand still have a positive impact on new product introductions in nonseasonal frequencies, although somewhat weaker than before. Fluctuations in aggregate demand again influence new products more than respective fluctuations in market demand. Also, new product introductions in Instruments and Electrical Machinery are much more responsive to market and aggregate demand than in other industries, and the ones in Transportation Equipment are the least responsive among the five industries in the sample. Overall, the results do not seem to be sensitive to the methodology used in seasonally adjusting the series on new product introductions.

The discussion so far presents strong evidence in favor of the premise that new product introductions are driven by seasonal and nonseasonal fluctuations in market and aggregate demand. However, in a Schumpeterian tradition, some might claim that the introduction of new products through “creative destruction” can become the driving force of the fluctuations in economic activity instead of following them as the present study demonstrates. To explore this premise, I regressed the log of industrial production and also the log growth rate of it (proxies of economic activity) on their past values (up to 2 monthly lags) and the concurrent level of new product introductions along with up to 3 monthly lags. In all industries in the sample, except in Transportation Equipment, new product introductions did not have any statistically significant impact on either the level or the growth rate of industrial production.18Therefore, the possibility for new products to lead the fluctuations in economic activity seems rather remote.19

fn.p: The two methodologies in seasonally adjusting the new product introductions series are similar since they have a correlation of 0.807.

In Transportation Equipment the log level of new product introductions has a positive and statistically significant impact on the log level of industrial production. Also, the log level of new products along with its 1‐month lag has a positive and statistically significant impact on the log growth rate of industrial production.
The results from these regressions are not reported in the article but are available on request from the author.

sec.label: VII.
sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This article sheds light on the timing patterns of new product introduction in some U.S. manufacturing industries. The findings, consistent with ample anecdotal evidence, identify the time structure of the variability of new product introductions and also help in measuring the impact of market and aggregate demand fluctuations on the timing of new product introductions.

New product introductions vary much more in nonseasonal frequencies than they do in seasonal frequencies. Also, the seasons alone account for only a small part of the total variability of new product introductions, with other factors being much more important. In this analysis I focus on the importance of market and aggregate demand fluctuations in explaining the timing of new product introductions.

Market and aggregate demand fluctuations account for between 35% and 80% of the seasonal variability of new product introductions in various industries, while they contribute approximately 17%–43% to the nonseasonal variability of new product introductions in the same industries. Market and aggregate demand are most important for the timing of new product introductions in Electrical Machinery and least important in Instruments and Related Products. Also, new product introductions respond more to fluctuations in aggregate demand than in market demand. At the same time, they respond more to demand fluctuations in business cycle frequencies than in seasonal frequencies. Finally, these results are robust to different types and treatment of the data.

The empirical findings of this article do not set up a normative recommendation framework to companies for the optimal timing of their new product introductions. Instead, they unveil the structure of the timing path of new product introductions, putting emphasis on market and aggregate demand expansions as important driving forces in determining the timing for new product introductions. On the other hand, they shed light on theoretical findings by others. For instance, the finding that new product introductions follow seasonal patterns is consistent with the theoretical claim in Pashigian and Bowen (1991), Lazear (1986), and Courty and Li (1999) that attributes the observed seasonal patterns of store sales to the presence of more new products in the market. Of course, a natural extension of this article would be to include more industries in the sample, since different industries might show different patterns in new product introductions. This is in future research plans.

sec.title: Data Sources
sec.p: New product introductions: the number of new products introduced in all two‐digit SIC U.S. industries as recorded through abstracts and articles in theWall Street Journal. Source:Wall Street Journal, 1984–93.
Industrial production: the index of real industrial production for all five industries and for manufacturing. Source: U.S. Federal Reserve Bank, 1984–93.
Retail sales: the real value of retail sales for the industries in the sample (in millions of dollars, seasonally adjusted). Source: U.S. Department of Commerce, Bureau of Economic Analysis, 1984–93.

sec.title: New Product Introductions
sec.p: Using the Dow Jones Retrieval Service, 8,324Wall Street Journalabstracts (and, if necessary, the corresponding articles) were reviewed for information on new product introductions. The search finally resulted in recording a total of 3,669 new product introductions classified per industry (in all two‐digit SIC code U.S. manufacturing industries) and on a monthly basis. For the search, the following key words were used:announce, launch, release, introduce, unveil, update, face‐lift, improve, along withnew product(s), existing product(s), new line(s), and new model(s). Some examples from the search follow.

Example1. “Today Eastman Kodak Co. plans to introduce a consumer film and five cameras: a single‐use camera for taking portraits, two compact 35 mm models and two models of Star cameras” (“Eastman Kodak Co. New Film and Five Cameras Set for Introduction,”Wall Street Journal, February 10, 1993).
In the data set, I included six new products in the Electrical Machinery industry (36) in February 1993.

Example2. “During the Oscars tonight, GM will launch the latest version of the Camaro with a teaser” (“Autos: New Camaro Steers Tricky Route to Win Import Buyers but Keep Muscle‐Car Fans,”Wall Street Journal, March 29, 1993).
This product was classified in the Transportation Equipment industry (37) in March 1993.

Example3. “Ford Motor Co. said a restyled version of its Mustang sports car will appear in dealer showrooms Dec. 27” (“Business Brief—Ford Motor Co.: Redesigned Mustang for ’94 Goes to Dealers in December,”Wall Street Journal, April 8, 1993).
This product introduction was not recorded in the data set since there was a time lag between the date when the product was made available on the market and the date of the article.

Example4. “Scheduled for market introduction early next year is Kodak’s automated PCD Imaging Workstation 6600, which can scan film onto Photo disks almost three times faster than before and requires less manpower for operation” (Wall Street Journal, November 12, 1993).
This product was not recorded in the data set since it was not clear when the product would be available on the market.

caption.title: Seasonality and Cyclicality of New Products
